postcard  MARQUET - Les Trois Bateaux.  1916  Three Boats.  Collection particulière, Mont  balance of caption covered by a Par Avion stamp
postmark   75 - PARIS 43  R. LITTRE (6E)   19 XI 68  REPUBLIQUE FRANÇAISE  075  POSTES

MR 7 MRS. JACK CONROY
701 FISK Ave.  
MOBERLY,  MO  65270  U.S.A.

Nov. 19
Dear Jack & Gladys

   Visited the Fabre's yesterday and had a very pleasant day.  Many many thanks.   He was most helpful with material about what happened after May &  June here.  Paris is lovely as you well know.  You really should have another look at it.

Ruth
Completed

in pencil in top right margin  [1972]
Jack:  underlined:  Destroy after reading -
233 N. Bliss
Anchorage, AK 99504
August 15th
Dear Frank -  added in different ink and circled:  Mead

   I was going to start this letter last night but we got company and I was interrupted.  Tonight Eldon showed me the enclosed article about the Hobo Convention in Britt, Iowa which mentions our old friend Hobo Benson.  Hayes used to correspond with him and he always visited when he came thru Chicago on his yearly trek to Britt.  Notice even the snide reference to the wobblies.
    I had a letter from Helene Vexer.  You may remember that Jimmy corresponded with her and since I am here, close to Mt. McKinley and the places where her father is sometimes remembered, sometimes maligned, I, too, write whenever anyone refers to Dr. Cook.  Last year, for example, one of the local free papers which records some Alaska history, mentioned Dr. Cook's climb to Mt. McKinley disparagingly and now this year she has written an article in rebuttal.  Her health was bad last year but she is now fully recovered.  She asked what I remembered about the publication of Return from the Pole.  Jack got the manuscript from Eileen O'Connor and Pelligrini and Cudahy published it and he visited Helene in Buffalo but that's about all I remember.  Do you recall anything more?  I'll bet Jimmy would have remembered some more details.
Completed

Do you have an address for Bill Weslake?  I'd like to try writing him to see if he remembers anything.  He's done some extensive reading about the Antarctic and Greenland.  I remember one of the intense lectures he gave for Pat Trevis in a restaurant in Chicago.  He came with books and maps and all the knowledge he had accumulated.  He wasn't only concerned with the Cook-Peary controversy, he was interested in everything in the Northwest Territories and Alaska.
   How are you these days?  I wonder if you're still calling Chicago home?  About a month ago, I "resigned" from RCA by invitation because I didn't fit into the establishment (not even such as it is in Anchorage) but what really startled them was my pro-union convictions.  They hired a replacement while I was still on the job hoping I would train her before I "resigned."  But, I left as soon as I landed another job and am now working with a law firm similar to the one I worked for in Chicago.  It's a pleasure to work with mature, friendly people.  RCA was full of paranoids, hopelessly entangled with New York strings and never quite sure who was ruling what roost.
   There were attempts to organize but anyone who was seriously interested was fired or sought work somewhere else.  There were even rumors that the union, the Teamsters, made a deal with RCA
Completed

2
management to turn in the people who were interested in union.  Anyway, two or three months after an open meeting, five people who attended that meeting  had left.  

   The man I work for now is attorney for the Ironworkers Union and handles the pension funds, the collective bargaining contract, the whole works.  He is honest and a pretty good attorney.  His father is a judge in the U.S. District Court.
    Eldon and I have come a long way from riding freight trains but we're headed in the same direction.   We now have a tent.  It's called a prairie schooner and it has a sewn in floor and is mosquito proof which is quite an asset in these parts.  We gave it a good workout on vacation, going first to Homer and then to Fairbanks and Circle.  Circle is on the Yukon River about 60 miles from the Arctic Circle and it was a pleasant remote spot.  We've added to our family - our dog had 11 pups and we took them all on the road with us.  We now have four but as they get bigger they're quite a houseful.  We have a big yard and they eat, chew on one another and play most of the time.  We spent one week end hiking and prospecting and would like to get on back but Eldon has had a pain in his back since the last climb so we've been staying close to home.  It will keep until we feel up to hiking again but since the price of gold is now $64- an ounce it is tempting to keep at it.
Completed

We are gradually making friends here.  I believe that as you get older you have a lot of acquaintances but few dear trusted friends.  These are part of a different lifetime perhaps.
    So, Frank, before I wax philosophical and maudlin do write whenever you can and if you correspond with Bill send his address.  I'll be interested in whatever you can recall about the publication of Return from the Pole.  Think it all happened in the early 50's.  The book may be published in paperback.  It is very readable and had some good pictures.
  For those of us who hang on - Ruth added in different ink:  Sheridan
Completed

in pencil in top margin  Sheridan, Ruth
P.O. Box 8114  Anchorage, Alas  99508   
March 6, 1975
Dear Jack -

      Got a letter today from Gene Nelson and learned of your forthcoming autobiography, I should say, already published, autobiography.  Gene flatters me by saying I should review it.  I think he'd do a much better job, faster, more workmanlike and very simpatico.  So by all means have your publisher send him a review copy.  I'm bogged down in a work syndrome for the next three years until I can join my retired friends.  I'm dropping out as soon as the system says I can collect.
    I recall that in our exchange of Christmas greetings you were surprised there was a University in Anchorage.  There are two.  The University of Alaska here is a junior, senior and community college and the big squak [sic] among the teachers is that the administration in Fairbanks controls the strings and calls the financial tune, so that instructors were getting a better deal in Fairbanks.   Living costs are now approximately the same in both cities.  The state has money.  I mention this because I felt you might be thinking about lecturing here.  If you were I might be able to make some inquiries although I have no "influence" as such.  The instructor who taught the history course I took in the fall left for Bordeaux to study there for nine months.  However, the head of the A.CC. branch of the teachers union is a member of the English Dept.  Her name is Edie Lynch.  The other college is AMU, funded by Atlantic Richfield money and the Methodists.
Completed

Fred Thompson wrote a few weeks ago and mentioned that there was a good review of Writers in Revolt in Labor History, a monthly publication that he's very fond of.  We don't get it here but perhaps you already know of the review.  Fred's at 2525 N. St. Louis, Chicago 60647 and since he subscribes to Labor History he'd probably send you the review if you haven't seen it.
    This winter I read for the first time Richard Wright's Black Boy.  It had terrific impact, far more than Native Son because it wasn't a contrived story.  Also gained sufficient momentum from the "Revolution" class to read more on anarchy - particularly the Russian anarchists.  So another winter has passed - cold, comfortable - and we have the prospect of the nice long beautiful days and some more searching for that elusive gold.  I hope to visit in Chicago and N.Y. in the fall and check out some of my wandering family.   Lenore's working for the Trots in New York.  Harry's in Maywood and is a probation officer while Ev continues to flounder in San Francisco.  She was here almost a year but Anchorage is pretty confining.

Regards to you & Gladys - Ruth
P.S. The IWW got a recent bequest, about $5,000, for literature and educational materials.  Each time their finances fade a way, some thoughtful fellowworker leaves an insurance policy or some hard earned pension, and off they go for another couple of years.
Completed

this letter begins on the following page,   992006198805867_midwest_ms_conroy_box_00027_fl_01411_000016.jpg

front and back of note card  File:Drawing of mountain and trees
PATCO people but the union president said no.   They didn't want to be associated with the IWW.  That wasn't his feeling, that was the International.

   I keep  listening and watching - even think now and then.  Last couple of years have been good for me.  I am retired but work occasionally so I can collect unemployment insurance.  It's a good  hype and supplements a widow's pension.  so brother Jack & sister Gladys - here's to another year in our long lives.  Wish we were close enough to share a shot of C.C. -

Warm regards -  Ruth
Completed

this is the first part of the letter that ends on the preceding page, 992006198805867_midwest_ms_conroy_box_00027_fl_01411_000015.jpg 
in pencil in top margin  Sheridan, Ruth
Dec. 1981
Dear Jack & Gladys,-

   Frank Mead wrote giving news of you two.  I'm still hanging in in the land of oil, coal, gas and countless other natural resources.  Matter of fact I've embarked on a new career - bookstore partner.  That feminist bookstore we had in our basement is now "up front" and downtown.  Found a cheap location and took the plunge right out there with B Dalton and Waldenbooks and our own Book Cache.  So far, we're surviving but there the momentum of Christmas carries us.
   I was in Chicago in September and attended the IWW Convention.  Not many old-timers are around - Fred Thompson and Carlos Cortez and then a host of 20's & 30's men and women.  I quickly found the Anarchist faction and then tried to understand what was going on.  The IWW lives, as it continues to die.  We went thru the motions of electing General Exec. Board members and a Genl. Secy.  Treasurer but so much time was spent doing this that we didn't talk about the strengths and weaknesses of the organization and where it might go.  Hell, just the fact that it is alive scares some people.  I mean this literally.  I offered to put on a support meeting for our local
Completed

[[postcard]
Mr. Jack Conroy
7027 So. Jeffery Blvd.
Chicago, Illinois 60649
Completed

postcard
Mr Jack Conroy
701 Fisk Ave.
Moberly, Missouri  65270
Completed

Dimension in the Fourth Estate at 65
How stale an evening paper is,
it has all happened, all is past -
I thought I'd try a morning paper,
get the news first, instead of last.
So I changed to a morning paper,
got the news hot, instead of cold;
This way I thought I'd keep abreast
of the day's news as it was sold
What difference does it make, if any,
to one who's lived beyond  his age?
Morning papers, Evening papers,
alas, fill an old man with rage.
Oct. 14, 1968   G. Sherman
Completed

Dec. 29, 1969
Dear friend,
How are you coming along with your autobiography?  It must be a difficult job unless you've kept a journal as Hardy did.

  I have written 15 short stories during the past year - 4 not bad - but Agent Siegel reported last month that his client said the weren't "in tune with the times."   What do I do now?!  I've been reading some short-story anthologies - underlined:  Story Jubilee & Stanford Univ. Stories.  1960 ed. by Stegner & Scowcraft.  
  You will be interested in the enclosed, I think, and will have some helpful comments on it for me.  (See p. 44 in particular).  Do you ever review books of the kind anymore?
  With best wishes for a productive year.    G.W. Sherman
Completed

P.O. Box 53,
Hendersonville, N.C.
Nov. 20, 1952
Dear Jack:

     Today, my birthday, Kathlyn sends me greetings as she always has since the first one after we became acquainted.    Kathlyn and Bea Walker took me to lunch at the Blackhawk that day.  I can't recall how she discovered the date.
     These photographs and the enclosed note should go to Kathlyn if you have the time to forward them.   Her address is still missing.  I would surely like to have it.
     Nothing has happened here since I last wrote except that this county's Republicans made a clean sweep of every office and included Eisenhower.

Sincerely, V. L. Sherman
Completed

Completed

in pencil in top margin Sherman, V. L.
Hendersonville, N.C.
Feb. 24, 1957
Dear Jack:

     There has been practically nothing to write about all winter except that we have no snow, lots of rain, temperatures above 70º and one cold night down to 3ºF.   Carl Sandburg had a birthday on a Sunday that was the foggiest I have seen down here, and despite a cold, took an outdoor stroll.  I get that from the local paper, not having seen Mr. Sandburg.
     I hope Nelson Algren suffered no ill effects from breaking the ice; but I wondered what he was carrying in the way of groceries that broke the ice on his way home.  And the ever-mindful Tribune did not say what became of the groceries.  Some day, when he has the time, I wish he would write me a letter.  I seem to be suffering from the side effects of Thomas Wolfe who is so beloved by the local sophisticates but not the natives.  Every time we go out Brevard Rd. we pass his "angel."
     If Nelson Algren ever writes that "dirty-little-boy-stuff", no matter how flowery,
Completed

in pencil in top margin  Feb 24, 1957
I'll never forgive him.

     Not long ago I took your "They Seek a City" off the shelf at the Library to reread early Chicago.  I wonder what has become of your co-author.  Maybe you can tell me.  I hope both co-authors are dealt with kindly by providence.
     We heard in a round-about way that Franklin Meine had resigned, but there were no particulars.
     If you have time, your tardy correspondent would like to have a letter.

Sincerely, V. L. Sherman
Completed

in pencil in top margin Sherman, V. L.
Hendersonville, N.C.
Sunday, Mar. 31, 1957
Dear Jack:

     This note serves to acknowledge your last letter and "Twenty years A-Growing."  Neither of us has finished the book, and you must read this to know why.   you will hear more from both of us a little later.
     The summer we were in camp at Ephraim, Wisconsin, back in 1913 marked our honeymoon.   We spent 10 weeks in a 9'x9' tent, with a miner's tent for storage.  The state park had just been organized and he camp site on Eagle Bay opposite the village was a paradise.  Our only neighbor within half a mile was a bachelor professor of English, an old friend.   We never took books or papers into camp.  The professor, of course, did.
      Late in June we had two days of steady rain.  The hornet who had built his single cell nest on the ridge pole of the tent refused to go about his daily chores.
      About the middle of the second day we gave up cards and writing letters.  It
Completed

in pencil in top margin  Mar 31, 1957
was hinted that I might ask the professor for something to read, so I trudged down to his camp.  His professional library didn't contain much that the average reader would get excited about, but he had a four-volume set of the Brontë works.

    "Jane Eyre" I had read, and didn't care to reread.  A frustrated woman never is very interesting.   But she had written "Shirley" and "The Professor'; maybe they were different.  Then came "Agnes Grey", by Anne Brontë.   [[underlined:  I wished it would quit raining.]   The fourth evening, in a "do or die" spirit I intended to start the last tale, "Wuthering Heights."
    Well, bed-time came, and Emily turned in.  There was a lantern on the "little-table" of drift wood between the cots.  I drew up a camp chair, an easy one, gritted my teeth and started in on "Wuthering Heights."
     About 2 A.M. I finished the tale.  I was bodily cramped as I hadn't been out of the chair since opening the book.
Completed

in pencil in top margin  Mar. 31, 1957

     Of course my acquaintance with the Brontë family was zero.  My first impression after finishing the tale was that never, in my experience, had such a story been written, and that the writer must have been crazy or drunk when she wrote it.
     The next day I took the first three volumes back to the professor, keeping the fourth volume with "Wuthering Heights."
     Why was "Jane Eyre" so well known and "Wuthering Heights" hidden from the public?  I questioned the professor who was way up and an authority on the world's literature.
      It seems the story was poorly constructed - the plot was not good - and the characters were brutal beyond nature.  (That same sort of criticism was handed to me by others of the literati for some time.  I was all alone and in the dog-house whenever I mentioned the tale.)
     Then in Bert Leston Taylor's "Line O'Type or Two"  appeared his thought of the possible pleasure of sitting before a fire on a cold windy night and starting out,  for the first
Completed

time, on "Wuthering Heights."  I felt less alone; it may be I wrote him a note of appreciation.   A couple of years later I found a "Wuthering Heights", all alone, in a soft leather green binding with a few of her poems.

    Time went on.  Then on "Invitation to Learning" the tale was brought up for discussion.  One of the four panelists was a woman.   She got to the root of the matter - what had puzzled me.   The three men were vague; apparently afraid to commit themselves.
    Well, you know what has happened in late years.  The "movie" was produced.   Because Emily and I won free tickets on my birthday I agreed to go against better judgement.  A beautiful screen play with a beautiful heroine but NOT "Wuthering Heights."
    Emily Brontë never wrote another tale.
    Neither did O'Sullivan.
    Now you know why I am going so slowly on "Twenty Years A-Growing."
    But, then, I will pick it up again and again, as I do  "Wuthering Heights," when I need it.
    We thank you.

Sincerely, V. L. Sherman
Completed

in pencil in top margin  Feb 4, 1958
the South for the same reason goiter used to plague the northern tier of states, diet deficiency.   Nowadays if one is on the ketogenic diet it is sometimes necessary to feed the patient yeast to avoid pellagra.  But Cash doesn't mention hookworm or its discovery by a shy agricultural experimenter who was pulled out of obscurity by Page for the benefit of mankind.  In fact there are so many people and happenings that Cash doesn't mention that I conclude he is just another of that contemporary crowd around Chapel Hill, Wake Forest, and some other universities.

  There is one little story in Battle's Journal that points up the sense of humor many Southern writers have.  Through the Civil War at Chapel Hill, and later, he helped with the state's financial affairs.  After the War some bonds were maturing and he refused, as controller, to let go to the Northerners.  "Now," he declared, "I'll get my name in the papers and become notorious or even famous.  Even the New York Times will run my name."  The New York Times did -- but they slipped.  "We hope there will be some way to uncork Mr. Bottle."
  Now I'll go back to reading Harvey, Pasteur, Lister, & Holmes.
  Give my regards to Nelson Algren and retain some for yourself.

V. L. Sherman
Completed

in pencil in top margin  Sherman, V. L.
V. L. Sherman
Rt.   2 - Box 426,
H ---ville, N.C.
Sept. 19, 1958
Dear Jack:

      The retracting cord on the typewriter broke, and I have been too lazy to fix it.
   The editorial in today's Hendersonville "Times -News" will interest you I think.  The editor, "Jimmie" Fain, son of the old editor, who was such a good friend before his death last year, has a liking for Negroes.  Someday I'll write about him to you.  The old man's photograph stands on the chest, here.
   The card is a sketch of mine, made for a "country fair" sale at the church.  With other wares for sale, especially bee-hive crossed out:  bans  buns, the church made off pretty well.  Edneyville is a community about 10 miles from here, about half way to Bat Cave at the
Completed

eastern edge of the county.  The "clinic" or hospital is well known from the work done by Dr. Bond.  circled and indicated with an arrow from before "clinic" to this spot  Bat Cave It is a community in the mountains just south of Bear Wallow.  All fine people when you get to know them.  We don't seem to be rated  here as "damn Yankees", but, then, all of our neighbors are native people and we don't live in the town's suburbs along with other retired folks.

    The sketch of the church reminds me of the last book you sent me, "Under the Trees and Elsewhere" by Hamilton Wright Mabie.  Gives one time  to  contemplate.  The door is alwas open if one wants to pray.  and there is more of an invitation to pray.   Emily spends a few minutes with it, evenings, when we sit on the porch.  But when the big moon appears over the top of the timber to our east, she puts the book down and contemplates the moon.     Sincerely V. L. Sherman
Completed

in pencil in top margin  Sherman, V. L.
Rt. 2 - Box 426,
Hendersonville, N.C.
Sunday, Apr. 12, 1959
Dear Mr. J. W. Conroy;

      What a comedown.  Makes me think of the time I discovered the name Wm. P. Schenek in Sandburg's "appreciations of help" in his "Remembrance Rock."   I dropped him a note saying I knew a "Bill" Schenek who was said to have helped him, but the "Wm. P." didn't fit him any more than the "Doctor William Graham" who delivered a sermon before the king and queen at Windsor, and whose title of "Doctor William" drew a laughable pair of verses from Punch.  Sandburg called me on the phone asking if he could send the letter along to "Bill."   What, by the way, has become of "Bill" and Fritz Lieber who used to edit Science Digest?  And the drama expert who edited applied science for Field's encyclopedia of wisdom (?) which showed Amundsen discovering the Northwest Passage 12 years before he was born?
     I haven't had a drink since the Christmas Eve of the year we came down.  But on the evening of Wednesday, May 6th, at 7:30 P.M. I intend to imbibe through some secret means in this stricken county.
     I see the University of Chicago is giving
Completed

the people of Chicago five golden opportunities to become more cultured.  God bless the University of Chicago.

     We are getting cultured down here, too, as you will see by the clipping.   But down here we haven't any "university background."  Jutting chins and plain talk.  Emily and I attended as "friends of the library."  The meeting was really interesting and, if crossed out:  Erie "Ernie" Frankel had been obliging enough to sit on his hands, easily worth $5.00 a ticket.  Those hands were worse than the detraction of television.  (The only television I see are the Friday night fights.  And I missed the one last Friday night in my attempt to become more cultured through the panel discussion. I missed seeing one of those dancing cuties (Frankie Ryff) felled by a spaghetti-eating toughie (Paolo Rossi) ).
    This is getting complicated.
    The library is pushing the children's department.  Since the library is really remarkable for its size, (I haven't been out of good reading in six years), and since there are so many retiring here from the midwest, possibly your "Child Horizons Standard Quarterly Review" might be put on their free list.  The retired folks might recommend it to their children's families back home.
     Your children's books and "They Seek a City" are on shelves down here.
Completed

"Artie" with John T. McCutcheon's sketches is a treasure.  I had not read that one.  I knew of McCutcheon's illustrating before he went to the Tribune.  As an illustrator he was of the very best.  George Ade was best at plays.  When they reviewed "The Ugly American" at a library meeting here I suggested they go back to Ade's "The Yankee Consul."  Some one wanted to get the consul's help.  When notified, the consul steps out on the bedroom balcony in pajamas and bathrobe and informs the applicant that the consul "isn't fit to be seen."  My remarks didn't seem to apply.

    If Don Russell is still with you and struggling with the "Civil War Round Table," tell him that I went back to "The Education of Henry Adams," for reference about Henry's father.  Putting back the book I noticed the two Volumes of Confederate administration "Messages" and "Diplomatic' Correspondence."  These were most enlightening.  Last Saturday I fell on "The Diary of Robert Garlick Hill Kean" edited by Edward Younger and published in 1957.  Kean was head of the Confederate "War Bureau" directly under Judge Campbell the latter under Seddon.  I have never read so much "dirt" about the Confederates.  It's most enlightening.  

Very best regards.  Vic.
Completed

in pencil in top margin  Shinew, Don
greeting card   Season's Greetings  File:Holly branch with ribbon and two small ornaments
Dec. 13, 1980
Dear Jack & Gladys:

   The two biggest kids here are son, Jerry's and his wife Angie.
   Wendy belongs to our daughter, Judy and her husband Marc Jaquillard.
   We just got a card from Jazzbo and he says he is fairly good for being 72.
   Time is merciless in its flight, - there is no slowing it down or backing up.

Our best wishes,  Don & Lill.
Completed

in pencil in top margin[Shinew]
[[greeting card]   Greetings of the Season   File:Round ball with writing in it
From Lillian and Don Shinew
12/14/81
Dear Jack & Gladys:

    There has been no word for sometime now from Doug Wixson.
    I wonder how his book is progressing.   I believe he had, or was going to get, a government grant in order to devote full time to it.  If that's the case the funds may be cut off under the present administration.
    Hope you are well and the spirits keep flowing.

Don & Lil
Completed

in pencil in top margin Shinew, Don
12/10/83
Dear Jack:

       Doug Wixson wrote me a while back that Gladys had died last year.
       We surely regret to hear those things and offer our belated condolences.
        The book is coming along slowly, Doug writes, but I expect you know about that.
        Hope you are OK.

Best regards
Don & Lil
("FAYA")
Completed

rubber stamped letter head  DON J. SHINEW   3781 Cherry Hill Court    Northwood, Ohio  43619
Aug 12, 1985
Dear Jack:

   A review copy of "The Weed King & Other Stories" came in the mail the other day.
    I have sent a thank you to Doug Wixson for his part in this presentation.
    As I wrote in Doug's note I am reading another book, "Gallipoli" by Robert Rhodes James.   It is almost finished and then I will get to "The Weed King."
    From the publication of this latest book you have evidently 

(over)
Completed

been very active since we saw you in Moberly at your day there last year.

   We hope you have been able to keep that sugar condition under control.
   Thanks again for remembering me with a copy of "The Weed King."

Yours truly
"Faya"  AKA Dan
Completed

rubber stamped letter head  DON J. SHINEW   3781 Cherry Hill Court    Northwood, Ohio  43619
Sept 6, 1985
Dear Jack:

   Thank you again for the book "The Weed King & Other Stories" and for thoughtfully sending on the autograph which is now pasted in place.  I have finished it and enjoyed the book even though many of the events in the contents are of course not joyful in that sense.  Nevertheless there is humor to relish such as "she", "He" and "It," the trilogy your Mother was enamored with, "the siren", not the story itself but the pronounciation, [sic] and the physical attributes of darling Charley.
     We are sorry to hear about the diabetes difficulties but hope it is now under control.   There are a number of people in Lillian's relation that have and still are battling that plague.
     Last night we drove down Byrn [sic] Road for the first time in over a year or so.  There are commercial buildings where you and we once lived.  Large apartments are common throughout the whole area.  Byrne Road and Chicago Pike, (now named Airport Highway) is very, very busy and makes the intersection extremely dangerous.
     Yes, I regret not spending more time there last year and not seeing Jazzbo.   We had a letter from

(next)
Completed

-2-
George's wife last winter.   The ravage of age has not been kind to either of them.  Agnes looked to be in good health and I was glad to see her again.  I would also liked to have seen Frieda but there again she might not remember the old Byrne Road times.

       There were two cousins in Carrolltown, about fifty miles west of Moberly we should have gone to see but didn't.   Since then one of them passed away.
       I would like to get back again but have no immediate plans. However one never knows what opportunities will bring.

Sincerely,
Don
-PS- 

   Did you every [sic] write about a party, who let on he was overly wise in the ways of the world and several of his companions fixed him real good by taking him to a sporting house and had him look through a hole in the wall for a good show and when he did that his head was secured like in a pillory and a big fat Negro prostitute appeared and rubbed her business in  his nose?
Completed

in pencil in top margin Shinew, Don & Lillian
greeting card ooo and Best Wishes for the Holidays    LILLIAN & DON SHINEW
12/9/88
Dear Jack:

     Lillian broke an arm in August and we have been delayed in our annual winter retreat.  We expect to be in Florida by Christmas.
     Hope this finds you in good spirits.

Yours,  Don (Faya)  & Lil
Completed

postcard
Dear Jack,
What a happy time to be in sunny, warm Tucson!
Thanks for your interesting Season's Greeting and please accept my sincere congratulations on the college reception of your fine work.
We're here until March, then back to Missouri to help drive away ice & snow if any is left.
Floyd
Completed

postcard   postmark  COLUMBIA, MO  MAR 14 2 PM  1964
Mr. Jack Conroy
7027 So. Jeffery Blvd.
Chicago, Ill.  60649
Completed

3/12/64
Columbia, Mo.
400 S. 9th St.
My dear Jack Conroy,  I shall always prize your fine sketch, underlined:  Theodore Dreiser, for its limning of a great author & for your most kind message to me.
We spent the winter in Tucson, the underlined:  Inland was not forwarded -- my sincere apology for not having acknowledged your beautiful tribute & gift.
We both are well & happy & active.
Floyd C. Shoemaker
Completed

in pencil in top margin  [1950s]
greeting card  And may the New Year bring you every happiness
Dear Jack -

    Visited the ?Schudlers? last Sat. night & talked at length about you with an old friend of yours, Sam Nevin.
     Are you "getting the good of it? these days

Sophia & Marianne Shrenk
(Gerald's gone the way of all flesh with a new wife)
Completed

Thursday
Dear Jack,

   Many thanks for Midland Humor  I'm using it to lighten up some of our usual dull moments - I hardly think I deserve it but I'm very glad indeed to have it.
   Been up to my ears getting ready for my show hence the delay, and I'm not a writing man, quite miserably concious [sic] of each damned word.
   Emerson and Diane Woelffer were here on thier [sic] way to Mexico to live.  Emerson was driving that racy looking foreign car - D.S.  P.S.O.Q. or whatever they are called, some mutual friends went for a ride
Completed

one nearly got pneumonia, the other having arthritus [sic] was hardly able to move for a week - as you sit on the floor with your legs straight out and worn out shock absorbers, and no top or it was down - but Emerson likes it - makes him hale & hearty.

    Had a letter from David Wagoner its a very pious University - he has to hide his gin in his room and drink privately or not at all.
    Bill Burford received a side swipe from his publisher, agent, and parents.  The publisher refused the book, the agent refused to handle it and the family said, "my boy make money",  and now he is negotiating to return to Yaddo.
Completed

I'll send you a catalogue of the show as soon as they come from the printer, if you know any angels who buy or create interest in painting send them to it, and when you are in New York stop to see us.

My very best, 
Charley
added in pencil  Shucker
Completed

typed in top margin  Shucker 1954
greeting card  SEASON'S GREETINGS AND BEST WISHES FOR A HAPPY NEW YEAR
Dear Conroys - 
Christmas just wouldn't be Christmas without your card and those very timely warnings - just at the new year's - We swear not to touch a drop - Charlie's 4th show in N.Y. will be in March - the best, of course - Hoping for another Guggenheim in the Spring & to go somewhere this time - Carrie is almost 2 - 
Love Charlie & Meggie

letterhead  NORTHWEST AIRLINES
In flight
Sept 14, 1946
Dear Reverend -

  I've been meaning to write you for weeks, but this flight home from New York is the first opportunity I've had.   I  have been in New York for six weeks working on a musical version of Barefoot Boy With Cheeks, which George Abbott will produce this winter.  As you know, I worked all summer on the script.    (over)
Completed

2)
brought it to Abbott in early August.  He bought it immediately and since that time I've been making revisions under his expert guidance.  The script is done now - except of course for the daily minor alterations that go on until opening night.

    I'm going to spend the next two weeks resting at my old family manse in Minneapolis.  On Oct 1, I return to New York for casting,
Completed

letterhead  NORTHWEST AIRLINES
3/
In flight
rehearsals and the road tryout.  I'll not get back to Minneapolis until after the opening

    We hope to open around New Years, but it is not at all certain.  So far nobody has been signed for the cast, although we have any number of eager applicants.  Lyric and music are being done by Sylvia Dee and Sidney Lippman (Chickery-Chick, etc.)  It's 

(over)
Completed

4/
their first show.  They're good and they're eager, and so for their score has been terrific.

    All my other writing activities have, of course, been shelved in favor of the play, I won't try a book or even a magazine piece until 1947.   And if the play runs, I won't do anything in 1947 but count my money.
   As you may have noticed I'm doing an occasional review
Completed

letterhead NORTHWEST AIRLINES
5/
In flight
for the Chicago Tribune.  Do not be alarmed.  I am still an anarcho-syndicalist, and, in fact, placed bombs in several postoffices on my recent trip East.

   Tell Algren that McCormick was immensely pleased with his volume of short stories.
    When is your children's anthology due?  Does Max Siegel still hate me for refusing to hawk books at that luncheon last spring?
Completed

6/  Is it true that the South Side Property Owners voted in favor of miscegnation [sic] at a plenary session last fortnight?  Has Bud Fallon gotten his Ph.D. from Chicago yet?  Have Dotty Farrell's drapes come back from the laundry?

    Write me at length gaspadin.

Yrs.
Max

in pencil in top margin  Shure, Eva
3-4-80
Dear Mr. Conroy:

       I never see your name without thinking of the day, sick as you were, you went down to help my husband, Max Shure.  I can't even remember what the Writer's Project had him down for.
     Max died in 1964.  He was forty nine and the three boys were all still in school.  But we made it.  They all finished college, went into teaching, engineering and law.  They all married; they are all daddies.  I went back for a degree, have been teaching elementary school for fifteen years.
    I think of you very kindly - I hope you and Mrs. Conroy are well.

Sincerely,    Eva Shure
Am reserving the Jack Conroy Reader - hope to read it soon.
Completed

letterhead  HOURS BY APPOINTMENT   TELEPHONE KENWOOD 3264
DR. MAX SHURE  CHIROPODIST FOOT SPECIALIST  3456 COTTAGE GROVE AVENUE   CHICAGO 16 ILLINOIS
Mar. 2, 1948
Dear Jack: -

    Perhaps you don't remember me.  I was on the Writers' Project back in what now seem to me, the good old days.  You might remember that you spoke at some literary meeting that my wife was interested at that time.
   You will notice that I am now in a field far removed from literature.  I have curbed my desire for writing and am chasing the lousy dollar - just like so many others.  Nevertheless, I have gone out into the colored community where I feel I can do my little for a people I admire (and make a living too, you should understand).  After living all my life as a so called superior white man, I have now come among real humans and am happy.
   No doubt you will ask yourself what is my purpose in writing to you.   There is no purpose except that I spoke to a lawyer who shares offices with me and he said he knows you.  His name is Mr. Marx.  I just thought I'd write to you.
    I have been following your career and book reviews with interest, so let's say this is a fan letter.
    If you have any foot trouble come on out here and I'll give you a treatment on the house, and then we'll chew our Project days.

Sincerely yours,
Max Shure, D.S.C.
Completed

letterhead  HOURS BY APPOINTMENT  TELEPHONE SA -2-3436
DR. MAX SHURE  CHIROPODIST  FOOT SPECIALIST  1187 S. Independence Blvd.  CHICAGO  ILLINOIS
Aug. 18, 1950
Dear "Longshot": -

    Keep away from the horses, unless they're the female human kind and have a nice buttock.  They're the only kind I ever play with; and if I lose my pants, it's for a good cause and it only costs me a couple bucks.
  I assume you are out at the Mansion to work on your new book.  You should be due with a best seller; as one of your most fervent fans I'd like to see you give Algren a little competition.  Everyone but my wife and I seem too enthusiastic about that - "Golden Arm" of his.  I was thinking of writing a novel about a guy with a coming pecker, but seems it's not news; everyone I know has a coming pecker.  That's why this world is so damned overpopulated.
    I don't think that girl ever did get Nelson to lecture for her club.  The last time I saw her, she wouldn't talk to me.  Maybe it was because I was looking too closely at her milk-bottles that she calls breasts.  My wife doesn't
Completed

trust me with her.  Her lastest [sic] ultimatum is to stick to feet and nothing else.  But feet stink, unless, of course, the owner pays five bucks for a treatment.

     Have fun, and don't forget to invite me out to Conroy's Folly whenever you have something doing.  If I can't be a literary genius, I can at least be a hanger-on.

Max "Hotfoot" Shure
Completed

letterhead  SPECIALIZING IN DR SCHOLL'S SHOES, ARCH SUPPORTS AND REMEDIES FOR THE RELIEF OF ALL COMMON FOOT TROUBLES

Oct. 22, 1954
Dear Jack: -

  We are moving out of the west side to far north, and my wife is in the mood for company other than the comic book variety.  We are having three interesting couples over on November 6 (Saturday night) and we would like to invite you and your wife over.  There will be plenty of liquor, food, a few records, no television, and as much conversation as you wish.  One of the men is a former colonel who, (Shhh!) when he's high, will admit he's a Marxist, the other people are refugees from the Warsaw ghetto.
   Our new address is 5424 N. Western Ave.
   I would like to know if you can make it.  I'm now identified with the Dr. Scholl Company, and you can call or write me at
Completed

the above address.

   I hope you are still  holding your liquor well  me - I'm just holding

Kindest thoughts,
Max Shure
Completed

letterhead  SPECIALIZING IN DR SCHOLL'S SHOES, ARCH SUPPORTS AND REMEDIES FOR THE RELIEF OF ALL COMMON FOOT TROUBLES
Dr. Scholl's FOOT COMFORT SHOPS,  Inc.   15 NORTH PULASKI ROAD  CHICAGO 24, ILLINOIS   SACRAMENTO 2-1808
CHICAGO NEW YORK DETROIT CLEVELAND ST. LOUIS LOS ANGELES TORONTO MELBOURNE HAVANA CAPETOWN PARIS BUENOS AIRES  LONDON
Nov 4, 1954
Dear Jack: -

   Nothing really happened.  You just jumped the gun before we really moved into our new place.  We moved to 5424 N. Western Avenue on Nov. 1st, so Uncle Sam's ? didn't know we were going to be there.
    We're sorry you won't be with  us this Saturday night - not only because you won't be there but because all that damn liquor will be going down Swedish and Semitic gullets.  I don't like to celebrate without an intelligent Irishman around. 
    I'm happy as all hell about the Democratic victory, but there are too many lousy Republicans in this country anyway.  Maybe we'll still see each other on the Writers' Project,
Completed

although it's more possible we'll be ducking atom bombs before then.

    Got a kick out of the literature you sent me and will show it to my wife tonight.
    Regards to Gladys, and if you  have anything doing at Conroy's Folly jist [sic] let us know.

Regards,
Max
Completed

Dear Jack:

      I have been trying to get this note off to you for all too long (it has just been too difficult a task to face up to!) to let you know that Lloyd passed away on December 22nd.  He was to have retired from the railroad
Completed

notecard   Mrs. Lloyd Emerson Siberell
on the 31st and looked forward to renewed activity in the world of books he loved so much.

    Forgive me for being so long in writing you.  I do hope life is being kind to you and yours.

Sincerely,   Ahua Siberell
25 March 1969

4 August
Dear Conroy -
Thank you very much for the book and the inscription.  I am sorry to be answering so late, but I have been away from my mail.   I live at 67 Princes Sq, W2.  My tel. is Bayswater 4068 (in book).  If you are free phone me, and if I'm out drop a card and I will get in touch with you.
Yours, Clancy Sigal
Completed

29 Aug
Dear Conroy -
I was dismayed, on telephoning Mrs. Wayblum, to learn that you  had gone back to America.  My schedule became tilted, and I had to keep coming in & out of London.  I did not phone when I said I would but a couple of days later, on Thursday, & left a message, and again on Saturday.   I am sorry we did not have a chance to meet; it was probably entirely my fault.  Thank you again for your book and inscription.
Yours,  Clancy Sigal
Completed

June 19, 1946
Dear Jack,

     I guess I have been thinking so much about you lately I feel we have almost made contact again.  Hence I will dispense with the preliminaries.  I discovered, of course, that Bill H. knew you, quite by accident.  He had returned from the wars, as they are saying now, and we were talking up at the house over a bottle of something when I mentioned having done some writing for the little magazines - and that means to me:  Jack Conroy.   After Bill and I made the discovery that we had a mutual friend in Chi. we really batted it around for awhile.  On his return from Chicago visit May 30, he gave me your address obtained from a fellow worker of yours.
Completed

2
some material (lists of little mags & an article I had once prepared and surveys of O'Brien re. ? The Anvil) which they might use.  But the book had gone to press.  However they did not need what I had!  I can see now.  I am living with that book in my spare time.  They have done a wonderful job.  In going over my "files" recently I ran across a postal card from Allen in 1938 which said he was writing a book on the little mags. several chapters of which had been published.  Which brings me to a point:

    Several Sundays ago, in going over same files, I gathered what letters of yours that had not been lost, and had my wife read them aloud to me.  It brought her up to date on one phase of my "past" and I learned many interesting things, viewing them in retrospect.
    Perhaps you may have noticed, that I have done a little writing & publishing of late.  I also have hopes that the old sketches will be brought out in book form.  More of this in subsequent letters.   I also have a "novel" in progress.  But I write so much on the job - technical and scientific.  But (again) I travel some, going into the mills, and I can not help but write down my impressions.  My wife, Charlotte, helps me a lot typing, taking my dictation, underlined:  discussing - in fact it is a joint effort.  I just have to
Completed

3
dream things up, it seems, and, magically, I come home and find a sheaf of clean white sheets typed like nobody's business.

    I am writing this at the office, which seems the only way, hence you must suffer thru these pencilings.  I promise to do better in the future.
    A million things have happened.  A bull session is in order.  Perhaps I will schedule a trip to Chi sometime in the future.  I was telling Bill I could not get to see you when our paths were perhaps 100 mi. apart but now I may.  Also, we have a house with a spare guest or work room.  The latch key is in your pocket if and when you can see fit to come Washington-ward.  My wife would come to Chi with me - to see the world.  (I am not asking you to put us up - somebody else will pay for that and I will make them pay).  But this is in the future.
    Send me your home address.  We are going to N.Y. over the fourth and will probably meet some mutual friends.  Well, Cheerio.  Here's a beginning.  

Fred Sillers  15330 Upshur St., N.W.  Wash. 11, D.C.
Completed

Dec. 12, 1946
1530 Upshaw St., N.W.
Washington 11, D.C.
Dear Jack

     I was very glad to get your letter when I did.  We had just returned from a flying visit to N.Y. to discuss problems of the underlined:  People's Cultural Union and its publishing arm underlined: Great Concord Publishers.  Your information concerning the San Francisco group is very welcome.  Just in case they fail to contact me, would you be so kind as to give their address?   This would not be a betrayal of confidence as I would simply put them on the mailing list to receive the first issue of underlined: Great-Concord Tide which will be out very shortly.  You, too, are of course on the list and so I will not take time now to explain the program; it will be covered in this and subsequent issues of the bulletin.  I hope you will like it and subscribe to the program as it is the grandest and only possible (I think) approach to the releasing of mass artistic ability and reader appreciation.
    I haven't gotten to underlined:  Slappy Hooper yet but will give it a plug at the Washington Cooperative Bookshop.  Believe it or not we have been underlined:  some busy on various things.  That was a grand tribute to you from the U.S.S.R.  The article in Saturday Review is also on our list to look up.
Completed

2.

   underlined:  Open Hearth, the first chapter of which you sponsored in underlined:  The Anvil, and, - in fact - the first literary effort I ever had published, will be "schedulese" by underlined:  Great Concord sometime in January '47.  There are two fine, thick novels ahead of my modest tome.
    I will have an article, underlined:  The Past and Future of the Little Magazine in the second issue of underlined: Great-Concord Tide.  It will treat of the relation of the little magazine to social and economic forces and point the way to the channeling of this talent and energy into a people's culture!  Ambitious or conceited?  But I think I have a point or two that was overlooked by Hoffman, Allen and Ulrich.   They were historians but flopped when it came to using their data and studies to develop a theory which can be a tool for the future.  The People's Culture Version is the answer.  (I was not one of the founders, incidentally, but I am contributing something now nationally, and hope to locally, along with my dear wife and helpmate Charlotte.)  Incidentally again, sections from underlined:  Open Hearth and other novels including underlined:  Chicago Pastoral will appear in Great Concord's anthology, underlined:  Answer from the West which is about
Completed

3
to go to press.

    You must have been thru a mild sort of hell, moving about.  I know what the condition is from observing people in D.C. (disfranchised citizens to you!)
     I will certainly watch the reviews for notices of yours & Bontemps' book.

Sincerely,  Fred. & Charlotte

   Enclosed, reprints of two articles for which Charlotte did a great deal of the research work and some of the writing in connection with the perenial [sic]  ? for suffrage here.  Spread the word in Chicago re. voteless D.C.
Completed

greeting card  SEASON'S GREETINGS AND BEST WISHES FOR A HAPPY NEW YEAR

     Are you snowed under now?  We have a teaspoon full of the stuff!  Best from us both to you two.  Charlotte

Dear Jack - Thanks for the bk - just received.  In the 1930's so much began "that has scarcely left off beginning" as Mann said abt the 1910's. - Though for me it has scarcely stopped being Depression.  - I wd send you my book, but, have no copies left, wd have to hunt it down & buy it and can't do that now.  - Maybe, if I pull out of this nosedive, I'll have peace of mind enough to sit down & read a book.  Now all I read is Help Wanted Male. - But the book - & the inscription .   Time for a 1930's anthology??
Felix Singer
Completed

in  green ink in top margin  circa 12-1 - '73
Dear Jack -

   Thanks for yr letter.  It was simply that I had this last submission to be made & there was the coincidence of seeing yr review, etc. as stated.  It was the answer I expected.  So I picked a pub. by lot & yesterday I sent off Submission #321 [approx. - as with the Kerchel catalogue, there is some doubt...] maybe the 93rd for HOGBUTCHERS,  and that's the end.  It dates back to 1958, not 1959,  & damn near sold in early 1959.  But of course they wanted changes - some crap abt making it a "Beat" novel or something - ...
    The way I felt about underlined:  December, et. al. is shown in Pt #6 on the reverse of this.  [ From underlined:  Small Press Review ]  I feel about this just as I feel about boycotting grapes & lettuce - same general idea   By now I've heard all the arguments against this stand - without being convinced.  What may be heartening, though, is that the editor of the magazine received a half dozen letters from Little Mag editors & mostly they agree with my stand.  In the past, they've resorted to all sorts of snide ad hominem attacks, breast beatings about their services to literature & elaborate poor mouthing.  [ One lament I received was typed with electric typewriter on 20# rag stationery embossed in two colors!]  Well - after  27 years & 14 books etc. etc. I'm happy to be through with this crap.  Mostly I've done good work & this shipwrecked sailor bids you & everybody else to keep sailing.

Felix Singer
Completed

P.S.   Since you ask about Fair's novel:  some years ago when I sent HOGBUTCHERS [I note appreciatively that you - unlike 95% of the editors & agents I've dealt with - took the trouble to spell my title correctly) to Harcourt Brace.   They came on with a lot of crap abt having to consult their attorney about my using the title at this time, etc.  I pointed out that I had had an excerpt from the novel, complete with title, in print years previously - whereupon they conceded the point.  What is noteworthy is that this is the only time in all those years that I was able to make a book publisher back down & shut up ---
Too bad you associate me only with THESE SEVENTEEN.  MUCH BETTER STUFF SINCE THEN --   FS
added in green in bottom margin:  Felix Singer
Completed

Hope it goes fairly well with yr anthology.  It does sound like a good idea.  We do have real traditions & one hell of a literature in this country - recently reading Mark Twain who is SO thoroughly American & at his best practically invented the American language - and we will continue to have one - if the kids stop beating their heads against NYC walls & go in for rolling their own smokes ---  offset & vanity pe processes make cheap limited circulation publication much easier, I suspect.  But that's no longer my concern.
FS
Completed

printed address label  Felix Singer  3023 N. Clifton Rear  Chicago, Ill.  60657
11/6
Dear Jack -
Maybe you remember me, maybe not.  If not, this letter is probably a waste of time.  At any rate, it's just a gesture.  I'll assume you do remember me. --

   In May 1971 I finally quit writing - after 24+ years, 14+ books, 300+ submissions - gruesome statistics like that.  I'm not the only one who thought my books were publishable -- a number of publishers also thought so -- but, in essence it came down to this & they said, 'Do it our way - or else"  - and I said, "No, thanks -- Else.  "  In May '71 I scheduled a number of additional book submissions - a time-consuming, expensive business, and, when you're pretty much submitting blindly, a futile business.  I am now down to THE last submission - probably it'll be my big Chicago novel, HOGBUTCHERS - and this letter is to ask whether you can think of any not-too-unlikely publisher.  Of course I have kept up with all the market data in the directories, etc. - and it doesn't tell you much.
Completed

2

 Question, then, do your scuttlebutt sources tell you any thing about publishers now looking for big novels?  No illusions abt anybody being crazy about big novels by unknown writers nowadays - no illusions or expectations - but since this underlined:  is definitely the last stab before I get rid of all my stuff - I'm looking for suggestions.  It's either that or pick a publisher out of a hat.  Of course, nearly every publisher has seen my stuff by now - but not recently - and no more than 25-30 times did I reach the higher echelons [4-5 times there were or - else confrontations]
   To describe HOGBUTCHERS is a task, I just dont feel up to.  I did so in a long summary of my writing career - which I wrote just before quitting - and if you were interested, I could send you those 25-30 pages which deal with the novel.
    Or, if you like, I could
Completed

printed address label  Felix Singer  3023 N. Clifton Rear   Chicago, Ill.  60657
3
send you that entire summary - of all I've written, learned, experienced, endured 1947-71.  underlined:  That one I'm underlined:  quite positive nobody will publish.

   It was written just to round out the whole trip, so to speak.  As an inducement:  you're quoted in it!  It's this coincidence that leads me to think of you - and write you:  that you are quoted abt Richard Wright & just last Sun. I saw your review of the Wright biography.
   James Boyer May, editor of TRACE, once mentioned you in a letter.  Dont know whether you subscribed to TRACE.   If yes, you wd have, perhaps, seen an excerpt from my novel in it ---HOGBUTCHERS, that is - got 5 novels.  [[underlined:  H] is all about Capital C Characters amongst the "Bohemians" on the Near North Side, 1920-54 -  My favorite two comments, both from book editors:  "You've captured a way of life" and
Completed

4
"You have created a world - and that is my sole definition of a work of art."

     Well - I dont want to bug you further about a matter you may not have time or knowledge for -- by the end of the year I'll be packing off some book, probably underlined:  H , for the last time [and damn glad to stop, believe me - my first book submission was Summer 1952!]  -- and I'd as soon as not take your or anybody's advice as to where to send it.  And -- I would not use your name as a referral without your explicit permission.  And if you want to see that summary, or a portion of it, no need to return it -- I have no use for it.  --  Good luck with this new book you're to have out soon.  As a further funny coincidence: a character in HOGB. talks of launching a somewhat similar literary project.   But he ends up getting married instead.

Felix Singer
Completed

P.S.  I realize my handwriting is a bitch.  Up to 1971 it was 95% typing; since then it's been 95% shorthand. *
note in left margin    *Typewriter lasted just long enough - broken in 1971
Been trying to get hired as a secretary, but those female chauvinist sows monopolize the field.  I'm quite awkward writing long hand.   And - am writing, frankly, against considerable inner resistance.  This letter does constitute an imposition, yes, and it's presuming on slight acquaintance.  But -- there was that coincidence in Sun. paper -- and so: one more quick gesture made.
FS
Completed

letterhead  File:Print of head of a hat-wearing man   JOSEPH THE PROVIDER   BOOKS BOUGHT & SOLD
Ralph Bruno Sipper  Post Office Box 156  Inverness, California  94937  (415) 669-1027
12/10/74
Dear Mr Conroy,

    Please forgive the delay in my replying to your nice and informative letter.  I have admired your work for a long time and it was a pleasant surprise to hear from you.   We are highly interested in radical and proletarian literature and I have mailed to you, under separate cover, copies of our Catalogues Eight & Nine which have a substantial section of such books (listed under Radical Literature).  
    We are interested in making an offer for underlined:  Chicago: City on the Make, but it is not clear to me whether this copy is inscribed by you, by Algren, or by both of you.  Please let me know about this and I will offer 50-60% of the price I catalogue the book for.
   My Partner, Larry Moskowitz is planning a book buying trip through the Mid-West in May of 1975.  Perhaps, you would like him to call on you to examine your library with an eye toward buying some of  your books.   We pay fair prices and, as you may have deduced from a reading of our catalogue, are interested in off-the-track titles.   I look forward to hearing from you.

Cordially,  Ralph B. Sipper
Completed

  Just a brief hello to let you know we're still at the same old stand, only it's been moved South a bit.  We disreputable citizens (anyone who deals in books is suspicious by definition) have to keep a step ahead of the law.
   Incidentally, in case you're anxious, item #1014 is sold.  It didn't last long in the rare book market.  I'm not surprised!
   Hope all is well.  Let me know what's happening and if there's anything I can do for you.

letterhead  File:Print of head of a hat-wearing man   JOSEPH THE PROVIDER   BOOKS BOUGHT & SOLD
Ralph B. Sipper  903 State Street  Santa Barbara,  Calif. 93101    (805) 962-6862
12/9/75
Dear Jack,

  Thanks for the note, the clippings, and for the nice things you said about our catalogue.
   To take the bad taste of Nixon et al. out of your mouth,  I've enclosed a copy of the underlined: best book I've read in a long time and one which I suspect will hit you - right between the eyes.   I've also enclosed a copy of my book review on it, which will appear shortly.  Let me know what you think of Sanford --  He's 71, has written 8 books going back some 40 years and has never "made" it except for his screenwriting period which was short-circuited by the House Un-American Activities Committee in the early 50's.

Stay well,
Ralph
Completed

letterhead  File:Print of head of a hat-wearing man   JOSEPH THE PROVIDER   BOOKS BOUGHT & SOLD
Ralph B. Sipper  903 State Street  Santa Barbara,  Calif. 93101    (805) 962-6862
3/23/76
Dear Jack  -

  Just a scribble in between doing catalogue descriptions for our forthcoming catalogue which should be out by May 1st.  I finally visited Ashley Buch, who is, as you suggested, a helluva nice guy.  I even got a copy of his short novel, underlined:  Beyond Laughter which we will list in the catalogue.  I'd also like to list the enclosed underlined: A World to Win at the healthy price of 50.00.  I think I can get that for it - if you will please write in the copy something concerning the book - why you wrote it, what sources it came from, who it was about (any one of those) - and inscribe it to Tom (or Dick or Harry) and don't date it.  If you have any negative feelings about doing this, then just sign it, but an inscription of the sort I outlined makes it a more interesting book, to be sure.  We're doing another radical section only this one will be called proletarian fiction and will be confined to literature.  
 Hope all is well - keep punching.   Best, Ralph - Thanks
Completed

letterhead  File:Print of head of a hat-wearing man   JOSEPH THE PROVIDER   BOOKS BOUGHT & SOLD
Ralph B. Sipper  903 State Street  Santa Barbara,  Calif. 93101    (805) 962-6862
5/4/76
Dear Jack,

   Call me Mr Wonderful (nobody else does), one of the first books to waltz out of the catalogue was underlined:  A World to Win, even though it arrived too late for me to quote from your lovely inscription.   The book went to the Lilly Library at the University of Indiana, where it is in the best of homes, and rightly so.
   The catalogue is keeping me hopping.  I thought that Nelson Rockefeller had all the money in the country (outside of the fortune that some one ripped off from Howard Hughes), but there are still a few people around who buy good books.  Just enough not to discourage me from going out to get a real job and not enough to permit me to lie in bed watching soap operas and eating bon-bons.  ah, well . . . .
    Let me know if there is anything I can do for you from my out-of-print book world.  And stay in touch.  I've got to cut off now to pack some packs.    Best, Ralph
Completed

letterhead  File:Print of head of a hat-wearing man   JOSEPH THE PROVIDER   BOOKS BOUGHT & SOLD
Ralph B. Sipper  903 State Street  Santa Barbara,  Calif. 93101    (805) 962-6862
3/24/77
Dear Jack,

   Nice to hear from you again.  The Mitchell book is worth 25-30 smackers if you can find someone interested in him.  This dumb business I'm in is trendy, to say the least, and sometimes authors are valued in inverse proportion to their importance.
   It is too bad about Ashley.  I spoke to him on the phone a couple of weeks ago and I could tell he wasn't feeling very chipper.  Let's hope he comes around soon.
   Things are busy in our world - Sunday I'm off to New York where we're exhibiting at the Antiquarian Book Fair, I'm travelling [sic] with wife, five year old daughter, mother-in-law and 300 books, so if a posse comes after me, I'll have to overturn the wagon and pick 'em off one by one.  
   Talk to you soon, I hope.

Stay well, 
Ralph
Completed

letterhead stamp  Mrs. Warden B. Sisson   721 So. Barrington Ave.  Los Angeles, Calif.  90049
December 19, 1968
Dear Jack,

   I realize that your opus requires more than just a Christmas letter, but somehow at this time of year I am virtually chained to pen and paper and underlined:  have to get my commitments written up.
   Yes, Aunt Harriet wrote me that you had been released with bitterness from New Standard.   Gosh, I should have thought they could do better by you than that - the skinflints.  I hope that Moberly more than repays you for that parting and that you are happy there.
Completed

We left Chicago at the bidding of the Navy.  My husband was a doctor in the Naval Hospital at Portsmouth for one year and on a ship which spent most of its time in the shipyard there for the second year.  I worked on a book of photographs of Antarctic algae for a professor at Old Dominion College in Norfolk the first year - until our son Franklin was born.

    The Navy released my husband after his two years - ten days before his ship left for extended tour duty in Vietnam.  The ship is a floating radio relay station and spends months circling 400 miles in each direction in the middle of Tonkin Gulf.
Completed

letterhead stamp  Mrs. Warden B. Sisson   721 So. Barrington Ave.  Los Angeles, Calif.  90049
It is still there, as far as we know.

  My husband is currently finishing his residency in neurology at Wadsworth General Hospital, a V.A. Hospital here in Los Angeles.  His training ends this June and he hopes to be able to do some neurology research here for the next year or so before he starts out in practice.
   I've been keeping busy with child rearing, a six month stint in Headstart volunteering, League of Women Voters and Hospital Wives Club.  My writing practice has
Completed

degenerated to things like telephone directories for various organizations and occasional letters.  I tried to take a correspondence course, but discovered that early baby husbandry is a 24 hr. job and not conducive to constructive creative writing.

    Now my creative efforts are mostly directed toward making clothes, thinking up new ways to say "no" and, repairing old furniture in better ways.  Oh yes, I'm expecting our second child next week.
    One more thing, please don't think that my referring to Harriet Thompson as "Aunt" implies any affection for her.  I knew she was pretty bad when I was there, but her endless chronicle of office intrigue is the most damning piece of paper I have ever seen anyone willingly write of themselves.  If you're out our way look us up.    Georgia Sisson
Completed

letterhead 

PHONE  UNIVERSITY 4-8289     RED STAR IMPORTING CO.  IMPORTED RUSSIAN CANDIES    41 ST. NICHOLAS TERRACE  Cor. West 129th Street  NEW YORK CITY

March 29, 1932
Jack Conroy,
Rebel Poets.
Dear Sir.

    You wrote a letter to me in February in which you manifested a strong interest in the Messelprom Russian candies which I handle.  This letter was in answer to my advertisement in the Daily Worker.
     There is a tremendous distribution of Soviet candies and other Soviet products, in New York and other large cities, but we are very anxious to reach the outlaying sections of the country.  I have spoken about you with Robert Whitcomb, advertising man at the "Daily" and he believes that, with your contacts, you can secure quite a sale, or at least interest, in these candies.
     I am making out a descriptive price list for you.  The carriage charges, as you say, are the greatest handicap.  Amtorg has an agency in Los Angeles, but they probably have to add on the same costs you would have to bear.  Postage charges would be too high, but if you can order a case lot (100 lb.) it can be sent by express at very much lower charges, which you can estimate in advance.
   Please let me have your orders for shipment or refer suitable prospects to me.

Comradly yours
Ralph I. Sitkoff
P.S.  I will allow you 12% off prices quoted on price list.
Completed

Sept. 13, 1934
Jack Conroy,
Moberly, Mo.
Dear Jack Conroy:

      I am enclosing $2.00 and ask you to send a copy of your book "The Disinherited" to my brother.

Mr. Sam Smedley
℅ Mrs. Finney
Route 1, Box 504
Chula Vista, (San Diego Co.)
California.

   I don't know the price of your book but as I recall it
Completed

2
is $2.00.  If more, send me a bill.

   I request you to put me on your underlined:  exchange list to receive "The Anvil."  In return I will send you a new magazine which I shall publish in China from January on.  But underlined:  do not write me to China except in the most formal business manner.
    Could you arrange to have a underlined:  review copy of your book "The Disinherited"
Completed

3
sent to me for my new magazine.  If so send it - and also "The Anvil" to
Miss Agnes Smedley
℅ National City Bank,
Shanghai, China.
Very sincerely
Agnes Smedley
Completed

letterhead  DOLLAR STEAMSHIP LINES   NEW YORK - CALIFORNIA TO THE ORIENT AND ROUND THE WORLD
℅ National City Bank,
Shanghai, China
Nov. 22, 1934
Dear Jack Conroy:

     Your London publisher has just sent me "The Disinherited."  I have read part one and shall continue until it is finished.  I pause in reading to tell you how deeply it impresses me.  It is, in so many ways, so like my own childhood that I forget it is a book.  I am
Completed

2
reading.  But, as a miner's son, you were much clearer than I.  It was drilled into your bones from your birth.  What a great and yet what a sad heritage!  The graves of your father and brother become the graves of my mother and sister.  And how like your mother was to mine!  My sister, reading it, wrote me from southern California that she seemed to be living her child life over again.  And my brother would not put the book down until he had
Completed

3
finished it.  As  worker, he said the book was just a part of his own life.

    Soon I shall review the book and send you a copy.  In the meantime, please see that I get review copies of anything you write in the future.  "The Anvil" is coming but it is nothing like your book.   You have a great talent, and I am sorry I did not meet you in America.   Your story is a picture never to be forgotten of the slavery of the working class -
Completed

4
and of its nobility.  How happy I am to read such a book by a worker!   May your talent never fade.
Sincerely and in comradeship,
Agnes Smedley.
Completed
